name: Kenneth Arrow
title: Joan Kenney Professor of Economics and Professor of Operations Research, Emeritus
bio: Main content start Joan Kenney Professor of Economics and Professor of Operations Research, Emeritus
location: 475 Via Ortega Stanford, CA 94305 United States
research_areas: Economics; Operations Research; General Equilibrium Theory; Welfare Economics; Social Choice Theory; Endogenous Growth Theory
publications: Selected notable works: Social Choice and Individual Values (1951); Studies in Linear and Non-Linear Programming (1958). Comprehensive bibliography and citations: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Dn8X_gIAAAAJ&hl=en. Archival papers and correspondence: https://archives.lib.duke.edu/catalog/arrow. Obituary/biography summary: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/21/business/economy/kenneth-arrow-dead-nobel-laureate-in-economics.html
_sixtyfour_notes: Kenneth Joseph Arrow was the Joan Kenney Professor of Economics and Professor of Operations Research, Emeritus at Stanford University, located at 475 Via Ortega, Stanford, CA 94305, United States. He was a Nobel Prize-winning economist, recognized as one of the most influential economists of the 20th century. Arrow passed away in 2017 at the age of 95. His research areas included economics, operations research, general equilibrium theory, welfare economics, social choice theory, and endogenous growth theory. His extensive publications are archived and accessible via his Google Scholar profile (https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Dn8X_gIAAAAJ&hl=en) and Stanford University faculty page (https://engineering.stanford.edu/people/kenneth-arrow). There is no publicly available personal email or phone number due to his emeritus and deceased status. The Stanford Economics Department general contact phone is 650-725-3266 and email econ@stanford.edu. No verified LinkedIn or personal website profiles exist, likely due to his age and passing. Archival papers are held at Duke University Libraries (https://archives.lib.duke.edu/catalog/arrow). The New York Times obituary (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/21/business/economy/kenneth-arrow-dead-nobel-laureate-in-economics.html) confirms his death and highlights his achievements and legacy.

title: Senior Research Scholar, Pediatrics - Center for Biomedical Ethics; Director, Program in Bioethics and Film
location: Stanford, California, USA (primary); Affiliate Professor — University of Washington, Seattle, WA
research_areas: Clinical ethics, bioethics, pediatrics, medical humanities, use of film in bioethics education, cultural medicine, neuroethics, medical education
publications: Notable documentary films: The Revolutionary Optimists (Emmy‑nominated), Rare, Worlds Apart, Hold Your Breath, The Vanishing Line; academic publications and NIH biosketch available (see Stanford/NIH profiles for full list)
_sixtyfour_notes:
Maren Monsen, MD is a physician, filmmaker, and clinical ethicist affiliated with Stanford University and the University of Washington. She is a Senior Research Scholar in Pediatrics at the Center for Biomedical Ethics at Stanford University and has served as Director of the Program in Bioethics and Film since 1998. She is also a Clinical Ethics Consultant at Stanford University Hospital and Co-Director of the Bioethics and Medical Humanities Scholarly Concentration Program in the Stanford Medical School. Additionally, she holds an Affiliate Professor position at the Department of Bioethics and Humanities, University of Washington School of Medicine since 2019, located in Seattle, Washington.

Her educational background includes a Bachelor of Arts in Art History from Stanford University, film studies at the London International Film School, a Doctor of Medicine (MD) from the University of Washington School of Medicine, residency training in Emergency Medicine, and a fellowship in Palliative Care at Stanford.

Maren Monsen is notable for producing multiple nationally and internationally broadcast documentary films focusing on bioethics and public health, including the Emmy-nominated "The Revolutionary Optimists," "Rare," "Worlds Apart," "Hold Your Breath," and "Vanishing Line." These films have been used in medical education and have received awards and international broadcasts.

Contact information includes her Stanford University email: mmonsen@stanford.edu. No personal phone number is publicly available; the general Pediatrics department phone at Stanford is (650) 721-5750.

Her LinkedIn profile is https://www.linkedin.com/in/maren-monsen-75a24a10, confirming her academic roles and affiliations.

Research areas: Clinical ethics, bioethics, pediatrics, medical humanities, use of film in bioethics education.

Publications: Detailed information on publications and research output can be found at the NIH Biosketch: https://cap.stanford.edu/profiles/viewBiosketch?facultyId=6131&name=Maren_Monsen.

Website: The program website http://medethicsfilms.stanford.edu/ was inaccessible due to server issues but is associated with her bioethics and film work.

Location: Stanford, California, USA (primary); Seattle, Washington, USA (affiliate professor role).

_sixtyfour_notes: Philip C. Hanawalt is the Dr. Morris Herzstein Professor in Biology, Emeritus at Stanford University, retired in 2017. He grew up in Midland, Michigan, and has a background in physics and biophysics, with a Ph.D. from Yale University focusing on bacterial responses to ultraviolet radiation and DNA repair. He conducted postdoctoral research in Denmark and at Caltech before joining Stanford University in 1961. He was promoted to full professor in 1970 and held the Morris Herzstein Professorship in Biology from 2009. His research has significantly contributed to understanding DNA repair mechanisms, including the discovery of "repair replication" and transcription-coupled DNA repair. He has mentored numerous graduate students and organized key conferences in DNA repair. Hanawalt has been actively involved with the Environmental Mutagenesis and Genomics Society (EMGS), serving in leadership roles and contributing to its development. He emphasizes the importance of mentoring and collaboration in scientific progress. His contact email is hanawalt@stanford.edu, phone numbers include (650) 924-6043 and (650) 723-2424. His personal lab website is http://web.stanford.edu/~hanawalt, Stanford profile is https://profiles.stanford.edu/5957, and LinkedIn profile is https://www.linkedin.com/in/phil-hanawalt-b2b71919. Location is Stanford, California. Research areas include DNA repair, genomic maintenance, molecular biology, and genetic toxicology. Notable publications include foundational work on DNA repair replication and transcription-coupled repair pathways. He has received multiple awards, including membership in the National Academy of Sciences and the Peter and Helen Bing Award for Distinguished Teaching at Stanford.

_sixtyfour_notes:
Michael Greicius, MD, MPH is the Iqbal Farrukh and Asad Jamal Professor and Professor, by courtesy, of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University. He is also a Professor of Neurology. He practices at the Stanford Neuroscience Health Center and the Memory Disorders Center in Palo Alto, CA (213 Quarry Rd, Palo Alto, CA 94304). Contact phone number is (650) 723-6469 and email is greicius@stanford.edu. He speaks English and French. His clinical focus includes Alzheimer's disease, corticobasal degeneration, dementia with Lewy bodies, frontotemporal dementia, memory loss, and posterior cortical atrophy.

He leads the Greicius Lab (https://greiciuslab.stanford.edu) which studies Alzheimer's disease and related neurodegenerative disorders using genetics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and neuroimaging methods. His research aims to identify novel genetic variants contributing to Alzheimer's disease pathogenesis, focusing on extreme neurodegenerative phenotypes.

His education includes Medical Degree from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons (1996), Neurology Residency at Brigham and Women's and Mass General Hospital (2000), Behavioral Neurology Fellowship at Stanford University (2001), and Board Certification in Neurology (2003).

He has an extensive publication record with notable recent works on Alzheimer's disease genetics and pathology, including a publication in the New England Journal of Medicine on APOE3 Christchurch heterozygosity and autosomal dominant Alzheimer's disease (https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMc2409320).

His verified LinkedIn profile is https://www.linkedin.com/in/michael-greicius-108358257, confirming his education and current positions.

He is highly rated by patients (5.0/5) and recognized for his contributions to neurology and psychiatry research.

_sixtyfour_notes: Philip Barkan was a Professor of Mechanical Engineering, Emeritus at Stanford University, with office location at 475 Via Ortega, Stanford, CA 94305, United States. He had a nearly 50-year distinguished career including significant contributions at General Electric and Stanford University. He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 1980 for his work on circuit breaker development and mechanical systems analysis. His research areas included design for manufacturability, concurrent engineering, mechanical system dynamics, product development, defect reduction methodologies, prototyping in product development, and variable valve timing mechanisms. He held approximately 45 patents primarily related to circuit breaker development and mechanism design. Notable publications include "Prototyping: a Tool for Rapid Learning in Product Development" and "A Review and Classification of Variable Valve Timing Mechanisms." There is a memorial award named after him at Stanford University, the Philip Barkan Memorial Award, honoring outstanding engineering design work in Design for Manufacturability. _sixtyfour_notes: Craig S. Levin, Ph.D., is a Professor of Radiology at Stanford University with courtesy appointments in Physics, Electrical Engineering, and Bioengineering. He directs the Molecular Imaging Instrumentation Laboratory (MIIL) and leads the NIH-NCI funded T32 Stanford Molecular Imaging Scholars postdoctoral training program. He is also Co-Director of the Stanford Center for Innovation in In Vivo Imaging (SCI3). His research focuses on developing novel instrumentation and software algorithms for in vivo molecular imaging of disease signatures such as cancer, heart disease, and neurological disorders. His lab designs instrumentation including position sensitive sensors, readout electronics, data acquisition systems, signal processing, and image reconstruction algorithms. He has nearly 200 peer-reviewed publications and about 40 patents awarded or pending. His academic credentials include a Ph.D., M.Phil., and M.S. in Physics from Yale University and a B.S. in Physics and Mathematics from UCLA. He is affiliated with Stanford Bio-X, Cardiovascular Institute, Wu Tsai Human Performance Alliance, and Stanford Cancer Institute. _sixtyfour_notes:
Ward Belfield Watt (October 21, 1940 – October 27, 2024) was a Professor of Biology at Stanford University and also affiliated with the University of South Carolina. He earned his PhD in Biology from Yale University in 1967. His academic focus was on evolutionary genetics, molecular evolution, and biochemical and physiological ecology, with a particular emphasis on polymorphism in butterflies, especially the genus Colias. He conducted extensive field research for over 50 years at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Colorado. He published more than 75 scientific articles and book chapters, contributing significantly to the fields of evolutionary biology and genetics.

He served as a Trustee of the California Academy of Sciences since 1997 and as its President since 2003. He retired from Stanford University in 2013 and continued research at the University of South Carolina until 2022. His Stanford profile (https://profiles.stanford.edu/6249) is the most authoritative source for his academic and professional information.

No verified personal website or LinkedIn profile has been found. The email address wbwatt@stanford.edu appears in academic publications but is not officially confirmed on Stanford Profiles. No public phone number is available. His locations are inferred as Stanford, California, and Columbia, South Carolina based on his institutional affiliations.

Courses taught include Teaching Practicum in Biology (BIO 290). His research interests include evolutionary adaptive mechanisms, genotype-phenotype-environment interactions, and molecular evolution.

_sixtyfour_notes:
Andrea Jean Traynor, MD, is a Clinical Professor in the Department of Anesthesiology, Perioperative and Pain Medicine at Stanford University School of Medicine, located in Stanford, CA. She practices clinically at Stanford Health Care, Stanford Medicine Children's Health, and Lucile Packard Children's Hospital Stanford. She completed her medical degree at Saint Louis University School of Medicine in 1999, followed by residency (2000-2003) and fellowship (2003-2004) in anesthesiology and obstetrical anesthesiology at Stanford University School of Medicine. She is board certified by the American Board of Anesthesiology since 2004.

Her email contact is atraynor@stanford.edu, and her office phone number is (650) 723-6412. Her clinical office is located at 300 Pasteur Dr Rm H3580MC 5640, Stanford, CA 94305.

Dr. Traynor served as the Obstetric Anesthesiology Fellowship Director at Stanford University from 2015 to 2023 and has held leadership roles in the Society of Obstetric Anesthesiology and Perinatology and the Society of Academic Associations of Anesthesiology. She is a member of the Anesthesia Diversity Council at Stanford.

Her research interests focus on medical education, obstetrical anesthesiology workforce, obstetrical hemorrhage, anesthesia practice, and women's health. She is co-editor in chief of the "Manual of Clinical Anesthesiology" (1st and 2nd editions) and co-developed the Learnly online anesthesiology education program with the Stanford AIM Lab, which provides a daily learning curriculum for anesthesiology residents.
